content:
Wayne, yes, very similar. When Thunderbird is open there are four instances of thunderbird.exe visible in the task manager. I hit File | Exit, and the GUI remains open for around a minute, then the GUI closes, and three of the four .exes disappear from task manager, the fourth disappears a few seconds later.

However, while going over this again I noticed something, the message in the bottom left corner of the interface was referring to my Outlook account "sending secure login information to ...@outlook.com". I checked the settings on that account in Thunderbird and set it to never check for new messages (it's a rarely-used account), and not to empty the deleted folder on exit, and since doing that TB has behaved perfectly.

So (at least in my case), not a bug, rather some failure to connect to the office365 mail server.
creator: anne.a.simpson

content:
Hello there We have read the messsge We try to help

For example, an add-on can cause a crash and an update can also cause one.

see if you can boot into the so-called trouble shoot mode option.

If you can boot up normally and it doesn't cause a crash then it could be a bad add-on that is the problem, track it down and remove it from your list of add-ons.

Also, this same problem can be caused in the same way with any piece of software on your PC that urgently needs to be removed from your PC machine.

This may also be a bug.

This can be reported if you want?

please report it to us.

creator: pcp04

content:
Accumulating messages in Inbox is a bad idea. The file grows over time and every time you receive a message the entire Inbox file is scanned by anti-virus software while Thunderbird needs to wait to write to the file. Anti-virus is the most likely to have cause Inbox file corruption which can cause data loss.

These are some generic suggestions to avoid problems with anti-virus software.

Create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-to-find-your-profile

Don't let your anti-virus software scan incoming and outgoing messages.

Don't let your anti-virus software scan attachments.

Don't let your anti-virus software intercept your secure connection to the server.

Remove any add-ons your anti-virus software may have installed in Thunderbird.

Keep it working. http://kb.mozillazine.org/Keep_it_working_-_Thunderbird

And last but not least, backup your Thunderbird profile on a regular basis. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile

If you do have a backup created prior to the incident that would probably your best bet to restore the lost messages.

To avoid accumulation messages in Inbox in the future take a look at the Archive feature. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/archived-messages

content: because sending and receiving are two different things and on most mail servers use two different physical servers, potentially with two different passwords. So they are requested and stored separately.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I don't fully grasp what you're doing, but I will try. - Since your intent is not to use the second account for downloading but to separate alias messages, I suggest you do this: -- set up an identity in the primary account for the alias, including sig if desired. -- change the filters to move all messages targeted to the alias to a separate folder -- eliminate the second account as that is a disaster waiting to repeat itself -- this lets you retrieve and reply to both email addresses from within the one account.

- to get messages to redownload to primary account, you could exit TB, and in Profile Mail\<accountname> folder, delete the popstate.dat file, which will cause all mail to redownload.
creator: davidsk

content:
@ David - appreciate some of the good thoughts - may need to ponder some info. NOTE: This Alias acct has only ~ 40 msgs addressed to Alias; all others were to the Master addy.

The only prob I see (this specific instance) is,

  • the mail TO Alias addy are already in the (separate) Alias acct;
  • Alias msgs NO longer in Master acct (moved to Alias)
  • Not sure can "just delete" Alias TB acct, as some Alias msgs may not still be on server.
- to get messages to redownload to primary account, you could exit TB, and in Profile Mail\<accountname> folder, delete the popstate.dat file, which will cause all mail to redownload.

Is this a good idea? ALL msgs (still on server) for Master addy will be re-DnLd'd to TB Master acct - duplicating most msgs. Seems bigger headache than now?

Only way I see that works w/o headache, is *if all desired msgs (Master & Alias addies) are still on server (not likely).

  • And if All msgs were 1st BU'd, then deleted from TB Master acct, so no duplicates land in Master acct.
  • If allowed duplicates in Master acct, then have task of removing 100's or 1000+ of duplicates vs. (current problem) isolating just 40 Alias msgs.

I can make BU of Alias mailbox files - won't solve problem - separating / removing the many Master msgs from a few Alias msgs.
creator: Joebt

content:
In part from David's ideas, I decided the fastest, easiest way to get all unwanted msgs out of the TB - "Alias" acct's Inbox is:

  • BU mail storage files from Thunderbird profile
  • Create new sub-folder(s) under Alias acct
  • Create filter rules to move unwanted msgs from Alias Inbox to sub-folders.

(Could drag/drop msgs to sub-folders, but a lot of msgs)

  • Deal w/ unneeded duplicate msgs - in new sub-folders, as needed.

Total time ~ 10 min (if know where to find mail files & how to create sub-folders & message filters) That's It! Thanks!
creator: Joebt
